conclusion: Consider principles of refraction and total internal reflection.
Light beam is incident at an angle i from the air to the surface of the transparent medium ball.
Light refracts according to Snell's Law: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r).
Light travels through the medium and reaches the opposite side of the sphere.
Light attempts to exit the medium back into the air at an angle r'.
Total internal reflection occurs if angle r' is greater than critical angle θc, given by sin(θc) = n1/n2.
If r' > θc, total internal reflection will occur, and light will not exit the medium.
Angle r' depends on geometry of the sphere and initial incident angle i; r' equals angle r.
If incident angle i is large enough such that refracted angle r is greater than θc, total internal reflection will occur.
Yes, if incident angle i is large enough, light will be totally internally reflected.
